passages.text: Must- Reads and Highlights from Equity Research

Nothing beats a Jet2- holiday JPM September Issue. Our Sector teams highlight their key views and upcoming catalysts in H2, and recap their content highlights in case you missed them (summary on page 5). We hope this will help you to both catch up post the summer and look forward to what we anticipate should be of interest in the remainder of H2.

Mark your calendars: We have \(>125\) EMEA access events into year end including conferences, investor trips, fireside chats and roadshows. The events are flagged on each sector page, alongside a summary of upcoming CMDs on page 5.
This quarter in J.P. Morgan CEEMEA Equity Research...

Less is more? China "anti- involution" impacts. Our sector teams explored potential implications from curbing overcapacity in China across key industries, with an additional note on Petrochemicals from Alex Comer.

MENA Banks launch. Mehmet Sevim reinstated coverage of ten MENA banks, with new OW ratings on five stocks including Al Rajhi Bank and SNB. After meeting \(>50\) investors in the following weeks, he provided feedback from across Saudi, UAE and London.

Upside in Abu Dhabi. Taher Safieddine detailed the healthy fundamentals that support his positive MT view on the Abu Dhabi Real Estate market, with a preference for Aldar Properties as a catalyst- driven, growth- oriented, high- quality play on the space.

SA Financials convictions. Baron Nkomo placed four Financials stocks on Positive Catalyst Watch into Sept, expecting near- term upside for Insurers versus longer term outperformance for Banks as rates and yields decline.

Food for thought. In Food Delivery, Elena Jouronova reiterated her preference in MENA for Talabat (OW) vs. Jahez (d/g to UW), while Borja Olcese continues to view Jeronimo Martins as offering the best risk- reward in CEE Food Retail.
Glencore: digging deep. Dominic O'Kane moved to OW (from NR) on Glencore highlighting the company's strategic optionality, production- driven earnings uplifts, and attractive capital returns.
What's trending? Highest volume of single- stock interactions in August: Atrego (Elena Jouronova), Absa Group Ltd (Baron Nkomo) and ACWAPower Co (Anna Antonova).
Conviction into events: 11 stocks placed on Catalyst Watch.
Upcoming Conferences: Emerging and Frontier Markets Opportunities (Sep 16- 18), Türkiye Investment (Sep 24), Tech Stars (Oct 7- 8), Global Energy (Nov 3- 4).

About CEEMEA Insights A lot happens in a month - CEEMEA Insights is the quarterly publication that allows our clients to stay updated on the most important content and events from CEEMEA Equity Research and on what's next, in one pass.
See page 37 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non- US analyst disclosures.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

Without China following through on capacity rationalization, the supply/demand dynamics are unlikely to improve in the medium term. We view this as a near-term headwind rather than structural, and we favour names with compelling fundamentals, including Antofagasta (OW, AFL). We stay positive on gold miners and are OW AngloGold, Fresnillo &amp; Hochschild.Türkiye Consumer &amp; IndustrialsHanzade KilickiranOW: Ford Otosan, Turkish AirlinesWe expect two key themes to unfold in Turkish equities in H2: a declining cost of capital attracts more interest in equities and slower domestic consumption prompts selectivity. We favour turnaround stories such as Ford Otosan (OW) and Arcelik (OW), as well as value stocks like Turkish Airlines (OW). For food retail, the consumption slowdown, lower food inflation and promotional activity challenge revenue and profitability while, in Staples, a lack of catalysts could hold back multiples for a few more quarters.MENA ConsumerElena Jounovova, TaherSafieddineOW: Americana RestaurantsUW: AlothaimWe anticipate improved consumer spending in H2, driven by post summer economic activity, stable inflation, and social/economic initiatives. We expect Almarai (OW) to deliver strong top-line growth, while post boycott demand recovery should support Americana (OW). In food delivery, Jahez (UW) may struggle with growth without reinvesting profits and developing e-grocery, while Talabat (OW) is poised to maintain market leadership and cash generation with a conservative profitability outlook.MENA Industrials &amp; UtilitiesAnna AntonovaOW: ADNOC Logistics &amp; Services,EmpowerWith regional PMIs remaining healthy and absent any geopolitical shocks, we expect focus to shift towards high quality cyclical names, such as ADNOC L&amp;S (OW). That said, there are still lingering risks for the global Shipping and Logistics sectors, including Red Sea disruptions and the sanctions environment, with the freight backdrop likely to remain volatile. We see further traction in recurring segments (commercial, retail and hospitality) as activity gathers pace post summer.

- Sector view: The operating backdrop remains generally supportive into 2H25 for banks across CEEMEA, with solid loan growth, careful monetary policy easing, robust capital generation, and higher-than-normal ROTEs. Greece and UAE are our preferred regions, and while CEE markets show strong operational momentum, political risks have increased, particularly in Poland, where we turn more cautious. For Turkish banks, following a tumultuous first half, the outlook is better into 2H25 amid the central bank's rate-cutting cycle. In South Africa, while GDP growth momentum remains unexciting at an expected 1% for 2025, lower interest rates and stable inflation should support both banks and insurers, leading to positive earnings growth and solid ROEs in 2H25. For Saudi banks, the investment case remains less intuitive, reflecting a weaker USD, low oil prices, funding constraints, and looming capital pressure at some banks, hence we remain selective.

- SNB (OW): The new strategy aims to re-accelerate growth, gain market share in both corporate and retail, and enhance sustainable ROTE to 17-18% by FY27E (2024: 16.2%). The targets are ambitious, yet delivery is strong as evidenced in 1Q-2Q25. The bank's favorable balance sheet positioning for the upcoming easing cycle is supportive. Valuations at just 9.2x 26E P/E and 1.4x P/TBV are inexpensive, while dividend yield at 6.2% is among the highest in our GCC coverage.

- Discovery (OW): Discovery is one of our high conviction names within CEEMEA, as we believe its new and emerging ventures, such as Discovery Bank, Ping An Health Insurance, and Vitality Network, are propelling the group into a new growth phase. These operations are conservatively valued in Discovery's Embedded Value (EV) at NAV, implying an undervalued Price/EV of 1.18x. In the upcoming FY25 results on 11 Sep, we expect the group to deliver strong operating earnings growth of 22%. Discovery targets earnings growth of 15-20% CAGR over the next five years, with an ROE within the same range, both of which we view as achievable.

- OTP (OW): We see OTP delivering >19% ROTE in 27E (20% avg. in 25-27E), one of the highest in the region, which appears attractive at 5.8x P/E and 1.1x TBV 27E. While we acknowledge the apparent lack of clear near-term catalysts and continued unhelpful headlines on macro weakness in Hungary, we see continued strong operational delivery, while the recent comments from OTP's CEO regarding possible M&A actions already this year make us incrementally more confident about management's intent to put excess capital to use.
- Central banks: FOMC, ECB, NBP and CBRT meetings (all in Sep, Oct, Nov, Dec)- Sanlam CMD: (16 Oct)- Old Mutual CMD: (TBC, expected Nov)

Macro and politics have been a mainstay of the summer in CEEMEA. Following the presidential elections in Poland, cabinet news and bank tax risk have dominated headlines, with the recent new bank tax proposal driving shares notably lower. On the monetary policy front, the CBRT has re- launched its easing cycle with a 300bp cut in July (current 43%), while the NBP delivered another 25bp cut (current 5%).

Sector view: Into H2, we expect modest downside risks to copper prices driven by unwind of US inventory and slowdown post H1 frontloading. However, we view this as a near- term headwind rather than a structural risk to the copper market and we see this as a buying opportunity for those Copper Miners with long- term compelling fundamentals, including Antofagasta (OW, AFL). On iron ore, we forecast \(\) 100\(/t for remainder of year. The key downside risk to iron ore prices in H2'25 relates to economic slowdown and any enforced nationwide steel output cuts in China. We stay positive on gold miners and JPM Commodities Research forecast gold prices to rise\) \sim 20\% \(to\) >\) 4,000/oz by mid- 2026 (link). We are OW AngloGold, Fresnillo & Hochschild.

Glencore (OW): Following a weak operational performance in H1, we forecast strong H2 with \(- 50\%\) higher copper output in H2 & EBITDA \(+25\%\) vs H1. Management indicated they do not intend to de- merge coal assets given the recent consultation with shareholders. Thus, we expect the equity thesis in H2'25 to hinge on a successful upswing in operational performance.

AngloGold (OW): JPM Commodities Research maintain a positive outlook for gold (link), forecasting \(\) 4,000/oz\(in Q2'26. We estimate ANG is trading at a\) \sim 15 - 20\% \(discount on 2025 / 26E EV / EBITDA vs major global gold peers despite offering\) \sim 10\% \(FCF yield (peer avg\) \sim 7\% \(). We expect Russell index inclusion and future development of its Nevada projects should help close the valuation gap vs peers (link)

Kazatomprom (OW): We see an attractive risk/reward profile, as uranium spot prices are gradually closing the gap vs contract prices (with intact positive fundamentals for nuclear outlook) and KAP continues to maintain supply discipline (supportive for market balances in short- medium term). Strong balance sheet backs well- funded \(\sim 10\%\) spot dividends yields.
CMD: Gold Fields (12 Nov)

Commodities have been broadly strong in H1'25: iron ore \(\sim\) \$100/t, copper \(\sim\) \$9,450/t, aluminum \(\sim\) \$2,500/t given the backdrop of risks posed by slower global growth from tariff risks. Precious metals are particularly strong YTD: Gold \(+30\%\) Silver \(+33\%\) and Platinum \(+48\%\)

- Sector view: We are witnessing the most extended slump in the petrochemical industry in 40 years, and our analysis suggests that demand is unlikely to bring the sector back to mid-cycle economics before the early 2030s without significant capacity closures/ reductions in planned capacity expansions (\\~20-25MTA for ethylene). Without China following through on capacity rationalization (through anti-involution), the supply/demand dynamics are unlikely to improve in the medium term. On fertilizers, urea prices remain high and the market is currently very tight, and supply/demand dynamics indicate structural tightening going forward given limited capacity additions and geopolitical risks to supply. Longer term, we do not anticipate that the urea market will get sustainably tight enough to offset material declines in EU gas prices as a wave of new LNG comes on-stream.

- Advanced Petrochemical (OW): APPC's new PP project (APOC) is now up and running and selling PP (30kt in Q2 and APPC is guiding to full run rate 200-210Kt being reached in Q3). Given the youth and cost advantage of APPC's new plant, coupled with operational leverage and gearing to an eventual turn in the cycle, it is our only OW in the sector

- SABIC (N): If we were to add another petchem name, we would look at SABIC - strong balance sheet, implementing cost saving measures and its fertilizer exposure should provide some offsetting earnings strength over the next few quarters.

- SABIC Agri-N (UW): Along with Fertiglobe (UW), Sabic Agri-N are the two stocks most geared to urea prices (\\~40-50% to EBITDA for a USD 100/ton move) and consequently have the most to gain/lose from moves in urea.

- China anti-involution policy: (October to March 2026): This new policy includes assessing chemical capacities that have been in operation for more than 20 years for potential shutdown, as well as a potential rethink on new capacity planned.- China 15th Five-Year Plan: (By March 2026): The 15th FYP relates to a set of goals for economic development which will span from 2026 to 2030.

As expected, Q2 earnings from the petrochemical names were generally weak, while the fertilizer names produced robust earnings given higher urea prices. The big news over the summer is China may be pivoting towards an "anti- involution" (anti- excess capacity) strategy (link). Importantly, this new policy includes assessing chemical capacities that have been in operation for more than 20 years for potential shutdown. For ethylene, Chinese capacity \(>20\) yrs old accounts for \(3.2\%\) of 2025 total global capacity, PE \(3.5\%\) , propylene \(4.5\%\) , PP \(4.7\%\) , MEG \(2.1\%\) , urea \(20.7\%\) and methanol \(7.5\%\) . Closure of the entirety of capacity \(>20\) yrs old would help tighten the market materially, though we see a low likelihood of capacity reduction on that scale. We suspect the more significant impact of China's apparent change of heart will be to the rate of future capacity buildup. We now see potential for a significant slowdown in Chinese chemical capacity additions which could well result in a much earlier turn in the cycle than previously envisaged.

Sector view: With regional PMIs remaining healthy and absent any further geopolitical and/or global trade shocks (similar to what we saw earlier during H1), we expect the "Defensive v Cyclicals" debate to start skewing towards more focus on high- quality cyclical names (e.g. ADNOC L&S in Transportation). That said, there are still lingering risks for the global Shipping and Logistics sectors going into year- end, including Red Sea disruptions and the sanctions environment around Russia's shadow fleet of oil tankers (link). Overall the freight backdrop will likely remain highly volatile. In the meantime, the expected upcoming Fed rate cut(s) in H2 should benefit most levered sector companies like ACWA Power and AD Ports and also help lift investor spirits in the (bond- proxy) Utilities sector, in our view.

ADNOC L&S (OW): Remains our high conviction top pick in the MENA Transportation space, as we expect the company to continue to deliver on its targets and also see scope for potential guidance upgrades (depending on market conditions) with Q3 results in November. Valuations remain inexpensive with shares trading on average P/E 2025/26E of \(\sim 15x\) vs ADNOC Complex peers at \(\sim 17x\) and blended peers at \(\sim 18x\)

Empower (OW): We view Empower as offering an attractive pure- play exposure to Dubai's urban development agenda, supported by a robust contractual framework and favorable tariff model, which also translates into attractive shareholder returns (2025/26E dividend yields of \(5\%\) ). We expect recent operational challenges (related to TSE supply) to be gradually resolved over the next 6- 12 months, which should drive EBITDA margins recovery back towards midterm guidance level of \(48 - 50\%\)

FOMC meeting (17 Sep'25): JPM Economists currently expect a 25bps Fed rate cut at the next FOMC meeting (link) with another potential 50bps cut later in Dec'25, which could be a positive catalyst for the Utilities complex.

The Q2/H1'25 earnings season for Diversified Industrials in MENA delivered generally robust prints across the board - 4 out of 7 covered companies that have reported to date delivered on average \(\sim 5 - 10\%\) beats vs our and consensus adjusted EBITDA expectations (ADNOC L&S's earnings have recorded the strongest positive surprise of all). In addition, corporate guidance for FY'25 has been either maintained (AD Ports, Empower, Ma'aden) or modestly upgraded (Salik, ADNOC L&S), implying a decent outlook into the year- end. Over the past two months, the investor feedback we have received suggests: 1) overall a continued preference for UAE vs Saudi names (which looks in- line with our CEEMEA Equity Strategist's call of being OW UAE vs "Neutral but vigilant" KSA, here & here) and 2) relatively limited appetite and low conviction for the more cyclical and/or more capex- heavy and relatively less liquid Industrial and Transportation names amid lingering macro concerns. Most discussed names in our MENA coverage over the course of summer were ADNOC L&S (OW), Salik (N), ACWA Power (N) and Ma'aden (N).

- Sector view: We anticipate improved consumer spending in H2 25, driven by post-summer economic activity, stable inflation, and social/economic initiatives. Almarai (OW) should deliver strong top-line growth through volume increases, poultry expansion and M&A contributions. Electronics players should benefit from a demand recovery, the back-to-school season and consumer finance solutions. Post-boycott demand recovery should aid QSR players such as Americana (OW), while higher travel demand post-summer should benefit Seera (N). Leejam's (N) aggressive centre roll-out may pressure yield and margins despite a seasonally stronger H2. Food and pharma retailers face subdued LFLs due to competition, with potential consensus downgrades following lacklustre 2Q25 results. In food delivery, Jahez (UW) may struggle with growth unless it reinvests profits and develops e-grocery, while Talabat (OW) is poised to maintain market leadership and cash generation with a conservative profitability outlook.

- Americana Restaurants (OW): We expect: 1) P&L recovery and profitability repair starting in FY 25E; 2) Confident messaging on recovery trends and progress on multiple self-help initiatives; and 3) A re-basing of consensus expectations.

- Alothaim (UW): We are more bearish as store openings drop sharply, with management facing limited growth prospects due to consumer shifts towards e-commerce and discounters. B2B exploration and underperformance of the cash and carry model highlight the challenges in finding alternatives to traditional expansion.
- Seera: Progress on initial steps for Almosafer IPO.
- Americana and Almarai: Potential developments on the M&A front.
- Talabat and Jahez: Keeta's entry into the UAE, Kuwait and Qatar in 2H25 may have a negative impact.
- Nahdi and Al-Dawaa: Nahdi may revisit participation in Wasfaty alongside Q3 results, which would be a positive catalyst while negatively impacting Al-Dawaa.

Almarai saw volume- driven top- line performance, however GPM trends were disappointing, impacted by price discounts and higher diesel costs. Leejam's delivery was weak with ongoing pressure on yield and margin amid an aggressive centre roll- out, while Americana reported decent trends indicating a slow recovery path to pre- boycott levels. eXtra (OW) outperformed Jarir (N) driven by robust performances across both the retail and consumer finance segments, coupled with a strong margin focus. Tourism player Seera witnessed healthy growth in its Almosafer division. Among car rentals, Budget (OW) continues to make progress on AutoWorld synergies, while Lumi (N) showed healthy resilience in rentals. Retailers showed a weak LFL sales dynamic and while seasonality could partly explain the trend, we flag high competition from the developing online channel and discounters. Spinneys (OW) in UAE stood out with its distinguished CVP, delivering HSD% LFL. Jahez increased promotions and reduced delivery fees in response to the fast expansion of Keeta, while Talabat delivered better- than- expected GMV growth with resilient profitability.

Aldar/Emaar Complex MENA Real Estate Tour, 15- 18 Nov

Sector view: We expect property market momentum to continue into H2 25, further supporting off- plan sales for Emaar Development (OW) and Aldar (OW). We see further traction in recurring segments (commercial, retail and hospitality) as activity gathers pace post summer.

Emaar Properties (OW): 1) A unique play on Dubai's economic growth story with exposure to sectors such as property, retail and hospitality; 2) Best- in- class brand equity supporting a record- high sales backlog of AED 129bn as of H1 25- end and driving ample visibility on future revenue and cash- flow recognition; 3) A strong recurring portfolio positioning the company well in the event of a potential market slowdown; 4) An improved corporate governance framework with growing focus on shareholder return (dividend yield at c. \(7\%\) ).

Aldar Properties (OW): A catalyst- driven, growth- oriented quality play in the UAE real estate space: 1) Strong development business (superior franchise, healthy market dynamics); 2) Growing recurring portfolio with exposure to multiple segments, LFL recovery angle from ongoing asset management initiatives and growing contribution from M&A; 3) Strategic land bank and wide product offering; 4) Ambitious MT guidance of \(25 - 30\%\) CAGR in group EBITDA over FY 24- 27E; 5) Solid balance sheet with progressive DPS and focus on shareholder return.

Emaar Development (OW): A high- quality, cash- flow visible, high- beta play on the Dubai real estate market: 1) Solid revenue backlog which cushions against any potential slowdown in off- plan sales momentum; 2) Strong P&L delivery over the MT; 3) Attractive valuation vs. regional and global peers; 4) Robust balance sheet with visibility for sustained dividend payout (c. \(5 - 6\%\) yield).

Residential property market: Off- plan sales activity into H2 25 is key for ED with new launches and potential read- across into revenue/P&L pick- up. M&A activity: Upside risks at Aldar from the deployment of further M&A (SAR 9- 12bn) and D- Hold capex pipeline (SAR 9- 12bn) guided over the next 3 years.

The Dubai real estate sector continued its strong momentum during H1 25, primarily on the residential property front with ongoing traction in transaction volumes and values (H1 25 \(+25 - 35\%\) YoY) and sustained momentum in property values and rents (+15- 20% YoY). We saw another record- high print in off- plan sales from Emaar Development (H1 25 at AED 41bn; \(+37\%\) YoY) driven by pent- up demand and strong absorption for new launches. We continue to see resilient delivery within Emaar's recurring portfolio, with record- high mall occupancy (H1 25 at 98%) and tenant sales \(+MSD\%\) YoY, while hotel ADRs remain well above 2019 levels. The Abu Dhabi property market continued its upward path, driven by healthy demand, higher foreign demand participation and controlled supply pipeline with Aldar's launch and sales momentum at record- highs (H1 25 UAE pre- sales at AED 17.5bn; \(+35\%\) YoY). Aldar's leasing portfolio continued its healthy performance supported by healthy demand backdrop and contribution from ongoing M&A execution (H1 25 EBITDA \(+18\%\) YoY).

Poland Trip,30 Sept- 1 Oct

Sector view: We remain positive on the CEE Consumer space into 2H25 given the supportive consumer momentum, though further re- rating from here will require an acceleration in retail sales growth and consumers trading up. Concerns about competition eroding profitability have subsided across our coverage; however, our analysis suggests that the Street is not pricing in higher cost of space expansion, particularly for Dino (N).

JMT (OW, AFL) and Zabka (OW) over Dino (N): We see a better risk reward in JMT and Zabka vs. Dino. In our view, JMT's 2025 guidance and consensus estimates are conservative; we expect LFLs to reaccelerate, with Biedronka margins having inflected. We expect Zabka to post an impressive \(29\%\) y/y adj. EPS growth in 2H25 on space expansion, mid- single digit LFL, improved margins thanks to increasing contribution of the Quick Meal Solutions category, cost efficiencies and lower finance costs.

Pepco (OW): Robust clothing retail sales momentum in Poland, the upcoming detailed disclosure post Poundland sale and the planned CMD are set to provide more reassurance on Pepco's turnaround story, underpinned by: 1) exit from the FMCG category, 2) improving proposition in clothing, 3) a more ambitious sales and marketing strategy (including the potential launch of an online offering), 4) improving inventory and supply chain management, and 5) optimisation of the cost of debt.

Allegro (OW, \(+CW\) ): The platform is well positioned to deliver strong GMV growth, while keeping margins at an attractive level via 1) expanding its merchants base, 2) tapping into underindexed categories (e.g. clothing), 3) benefiting from cofinancing and delivery development, and 4) growing its Fintech operations, while 5) concerns over competition from Chinese players seem to have subsided.

InPost (OW): In our view, InPost is a structural winner in the European parcel delivery sector with a strong unit cost advantage, though the current dynamic with Allegro is creating some risks to profitability levels in Poland, and the timing of a potential renegotiation ahead of the contract's expiry in 2027 is uncertain.

Allegro's 2Q25 results: (18 Sept): we expect a peak profitability quarter \((+CW)\) Pepco's pre- close trading update (25 Sept) and CMD (Date TBC): a detailed disclosure post Poundland sale and more reassurance on Pepco's turnaround story. Zabka's CMD: (1 Oct): updated strategy and growth prospects to be released.

Poland remained in the spotlight this summer with growth outlook, competition, profitability dynamics, implications of management changes and ownership structures top of mind for investors. Food retailers' soft LFLs on the back of unfavourable weather surprised the market. In the Apparel space, the debate centered around the major space expansion at LPP vs. divestments (Poundland) at Pepco while for Allegro and Inpost the outlook for delivery fees/costs was in the spotlight.

- Sector view: We expect two key themes to unfold in Turkish equities for the remainder of the year: a declining cost of capital is expected to attract more interest in equities, particularly index-heavy stocks like BIM (OW), while slower domestic consumption prompts us to be selective in our coverage, favoring turnaround stories such as Ford Otosan (0W) and Arcelik (OW), as well as value stocks like Turkish Airlines (OW). Among exporters, we see opportunities as domestic demand slows, with companies poised to benefit from favorable FX moves (EUR/USD), a low base in export volumes, and more visible margin repair in the second half of the year. Arcelik and Ford Otosan are standout companies likely to benefit from this backdrop, while Tofas may need a few more quarters to see the positive impact of its export ramp-up. For the food retail sector, the consumption slowdown, lower food inflation compared to CPI, and ongoing promotional activities pose challenges to revenue, creating downside risks to profitability. However, companies will cycle through different bases, with BIM benefiting from a low base and Migros (OW) facing a high base disadvantage for the remainder of the year. As the slowdown persists, staples lack the catalysts to drive their low valuation multiples for a few more quarters.

- Turkish Airlines (OW): The current valuation is unjustifiably low, with shares trading at nearly half the earnings multiples of the global airlines average. The targeted 8-9% capacity growth translates into a DD% FCF yield (as % of sales) in 2025 and HSD% in 2026-27. The normalization from peak profitability has already been completed and we believe the company still has opportunities to improve its cost structure as disinflation in Türkiye continues, leading EBITDA to grow.

- Ford Otosan (OW): The delayed growth phase has started in 2025, fueled by new export volumes for VW and a continued normalization in Ford Motor's export uptake. This supports the company in repairing its margins from a low base, helping EBITDA to grow faster in our view. We see no major downside risk to guidance for the remainder of the year and expect EUR/USD rate to act as a positive catalyst for profitability despite slower domestic demand.

- Q3 earnings releases: BIM, THYAO, Ford Otosan in late Oct/early Nov.- Others: 1) CBRT monetary policy decision on Sep 11, 2) JPM Türkiye Investment Conference on Sep 24 and 3) monthly high frequency data for autos and retail index.

Turkish Consumers had a mixed reporting season; with softer growth in food retailers, stronger growth in discretionary names and weaker performance in staples. Despite a few companies, such as food retailers, indicating potential downside risks to topline growth due to the continued consumer slowdown in July, there has been little change in full- year guidance. This has translated into weaker share price performance for food retailers with Migros and BIM underperforming the index by 7- 13%, stronger share performance for autos and Turkish Airlines outperforming the index by \(\sim 4 - 15\%\) , and staples in line with the index, except for COLA which underperformed by 10%.
